Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: identity-attack and non-identity-attack. Identity attack refers to anything rude or disrespectful about someone's identity, including appearance, race, gender, and sexual orientation.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: It's bad enough we already have all these American sicko's living in this country shooting up theatre, schools, churches, malls, etc., we don't have room for crazy muslims.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment contains identity attacks on both American and Muslim.
This comment is unrelated and does not contain identity attacks.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: We are living in a cesspool.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be non-identity-attack because it is not disrespectful to any groups.

Comment: You want proof? I switched to being a private investor this year. Started selling my funds at the end of January: put more than 1/2 the money in high interest savings and term deposits and invested the rest in equities, starting in May. I had absolutely no experience when I started. Just did a whole lot of reading and talked to people who've been investing for years. Invested mainly in blue chips. For fun, I check the performance of my old funds on a daily basis. Here's where things stand today, 4 months after taking the plunge: 1) my old TFSA fund, 1.33% YTD; my new TFSA, 6.51%; 2) my old RRSP fund, 0.76 % YTD; I have two new RRSPs: one in a savings account at @ 2.10%, the other invested in the market is at 3.21%: the plan is to invest more in equities as I gain more experience; 3) my old RRIF fund is at minus 0.30% YTD; my new RRIF is earning 2.40%. So, in four months, and with no experience, my investments are doing better than with an advisor. Draw your own conclusions...

Comment: From an economic perspective, those are one of the few things we should be spending our money on. Not the LIO, but the gasline, Knik Crossing, the Susitina dam and the Ambler Mining Road are needed infrastructure development that makes Alaska more attractive to resource extraction companies who will provide jobs and spend money in the state. We have to recognize that stupidity like Medicaid expansion has very little sustainable economic benefit, but infrastructure to important resources (better port facilities, natural gas, electricity, mining districts) have long-term economic benefits. There would have been no oil boom without the Dalton Highway, just for example, and when it reverted to State ownership, it opened up vast areas of mining north of the Yukon.

Some mega projects potentially grow the market economy while others are boondoggles. The "dump them all" mentality is short-sighted.

Comment: Funny you mention the Hell's Angels as boogeyman.

At one time, our society took a moral position against gambling, booze, and drugs,-- demonizing those terrible bootleggers and racketeers. But it seems we have a blind spot when government becomes the hoodlums.

Consider the many government-sanctioned lotteries. The payout is terrible compared with the old-fashioned numbers schemes, and I venture that the managers of these schemes earn far more than the former racketeers. With a higher payout, it took longer for gambling addicts to lose everything, and some of the racketeers may have been compassionate enough to tell their clients to knock it off,-- but like a badly designed disease, greedy governments quickly kill off their hosts. Judging from bootleg I remember sampling in Nova Scotia, it packed a punch, wasn't watered, and you didn't have to deal with sullen, overpaid, unionized government workers.

None of this augurs well for a government monopoly on drugs,-- if it ever happens.

Comment: I have friends who are retired and do "Grancare" for their four grandchildren. I love the daily photos they share. Because of my medical issues I can't babysit full time for my own grandchildren but I help out whenever I can. I love babysitting my grandkids and feel very fortunate that four of my seven live in our hometown. When I was a young parent 40 years ago daycare was extremely hard to find. I had never thought about it because I was raised in a culture where the grandparents and extended family provided care.  It was extremely hard to try to work and find safe, healthy day care providers. My grandmother finally came up to live with us so she could us. When she left I found a new program called a day care center and was able to utilize it until my kids started school. It was through a church other wise I couldn't have afforded it. I wish I could have stayed home with my kids but we couldn't afford it.Glad I can be here for my grandkids!

Foreign tax credits make allowance for the fact that foreign income has already been subject to foreign tax as allowed by treaty. Comment: That there were criminal gangs in the past is indisputable, but I think BP's point is sound in some respects, it was *for mainstream society*, i.e. MOST people, a less anxious, violent, conflict-ridden society. (Not because of RC faith, but for a variety of reasons.)  New York was well known for its violence, ethnic and other, as was L.A., yet the violence depicted in West Side Story for example was mild compared to what happens today, even in  Canada. It was big news in school if someone got into a fistfight, no one could have imagined using knives and guns and razor blades, etc.

Which is not to say it was better for everyone, in every respect. There are always marginal groups in every society, and being on the criminal margins was no fun, but for mainstream, middle class society, i.e. MOST people, it was safe, I don't see how anyone can dispute that. 

But we still are one of the safest cities in the world, and would like to keep it that way.

Comment: Bullocks.

1. In areas and times of extreme climate, nuclear power plants are regularly shut down because of the dangers they pose. In France the heat waves of 2003 and 2006 saw shut downs of the reactors (because of a low flow of water in the rivers for cooling) - just at a time when more energy was needed to make living spaces livable for people sensitive (elderly folks) to high heat. We're headed towards more volatile climates.

2. Nuclear reactors are regularly kept running way beyond their "best by" date, increasing the threats those reactors pose to their environments - and particularly human life.

3. Nuclear power relies on a steady stream of uranium being available for mining. The process of uranium mining is extractive and environmentally destructive. Sure, the power plant is clean, but what it needs to run isn't. Additionally, the US only mines 3% of the world's uranium.

etc etc

Nuclear isn't the panacea the nuclear industry would want you to think it is.

Comment: There is so much here to tear apart, I am not sure where to start?

First, Hood mentions his  40% gain in his home in 3 years, then says it is beside the point, but then ends his article with "My financial situation today is much healthier than it was just three years ago because I ignored my own advice, and that's pretty humbling." WTF?

His 40% gain is a fluke.  It comes from an extraordinary decade of the China wealth exodus, and in turn from Vancouver recently punting the wealth immigration east to Toronto because Vancouver implemented an empty home tax and foreign buyers tax first. 

Second, he foolishly compares his house price appreciation to the stock market appreciation over only 10 years.  When in reality the stats are already settled.  Longitudinally over statistically meaningful amounts of  time, which 10 years is not, the stock market always beats housing appreciation.  That's an indisputable fact.

Comment: Because there may have been court proceedings, doesn't mean the parents or children actually benefited from "due process." I retired from DFYS, the OCS predecessor, and due process was often found more in the breach than the observance.

The biggest problems I saw at the agency were frequent disrespect for the performance and ability of those who were capable of doing a good job, workloads driven by chronic failures to provide mandated "active efforts," huge turnover both created by impossible workloads and persistently poor recruiting and supervision, and a cultural milieu that treated responsible Native organizations as adversaries, instead recognition of them as indispensable partners. All the time I worked in the Northern Region, the only professional and competent director I ever saw was Rod Caskey, run out early by the Hickel administration which appointed a host of losers. The only supervisors I saw with a whit of common sense were long-retired Linden Staciokas and Tim Stewart.

Comment: For those who love a good game-meat sausage or jerky (some of my favorites), there are reports on the internet of how to destroy T. gondii. Much of the misinformation is being spread by cat-lickers who were born to lie. It's not as easy as just freezing the meat for a few days. They have found that even washing your hands and garden-vegetables in bleach and hydrochloric acids and digestive enzymes will not destroy T. gondii oocysts. It's one really tough bugger. It can even survive living in saltwater, this is why so many rare and endangered marine-mammals (all the way up to whales) are now dying-off along all coastlines around the world from contracting T. gondii in run-off from the lands.

For those of you who enjoy game-meat sausage or jerky, you CAN destroy the viable T. gondii parasites and cysts in the meat, but you MUST freeze the meat to temperatures below (MINUS) -20º F. The common home-freezer in a fridge/freezer-combo rarely goes down to below (PLUS) +15 F.

Comment: This is the slippery slope we've been talking about.  I'm not in support of  enacting law for assisting dying in general, though I can understand the compassionate response to terminally ill people incapable of doing anything for themselves (this whole issue was first really publicized in Canada with the example of someone dying from Lou Gehrig's disease).  

However, if this mandate broadens to anyone who wants to have someone else assume the burden their death, even though they are able to do this for themselves (like the unfortunate subject of this article), this is really rather horrifying. 

Mental health is particularly tricky - since, while there are people who never seem to recover from their condition, others do (and would be quite happy if their desire for suicide when they were depressed was not acted upon).

The issue is beginning to resemble how people choose to euthanize their pets.

Comment: Technically, you are correct in that Premier Two Moms approval could be 0% but if voters decide to hold their noses and vote Liberal regardless then they would win.

Historically, however, you are decidedly out to lunch.  

Usually, there is a strong correlation between the approval rating % for the party leader and the vote % the party winds up receiving.

With 3 relatively strong major parties in Ontario, it is possible for one to win a majority with 36-39% of the vote.

But no party can win a majority or even a minority if they stand at 16% in the polls and no party whose leader at election time stands at 16% in the polls will pull more than 24-25% of the vote (usually within 5 points of 16%).

If you have a persuasive argument otherwise, I would be fascinated to hear it.

P.S.  Take her greater public sector supporters out of the equation and Wynne-Bag is now at about 10% .   And we could be even worse off is the NDP aka The Notoriously Dumb Party takes the trougher vote and wins

Comment: Just to make it perfectly clear, the TAX CUT is not what adds $1.5T to the debt. It is the refusal to cut government spending that adds to the debt. If you have $1.5T less in revenue coming in, but spend at the same level as you would if the money was coming in, then that results in skyrocketing debt. You need to base your spending on how much revenue is incoming. Whatever comes in, then that's what you get to spend - not a dime more. That's called a balanced budget. And yes, Congress is NOT doing enough to reduce spending. Analogy: if you make $100k at your job, but then lose your job and find another one that only pays $80K - do you keep spending as though you still make $100K? If so, you're a fool. Smart people will curtail their spending to a level sustainable with their new income, like 20% less. You don't blame your debt problems on your drop in income, you blame it on your extravagant spending habits.

Comment: CPI uses hedonic quality adjustments to calculate inflation. So if this year's TV has better picture quality and does more stuff than last year's,  even if most of the stuff no one really cares about, then  CPI determines that the hedonic quality adjusted price has gone down.  One thing it doesn't take into account is whether this year's TV is unreliable junk that won't last, can't be repaired, and will  need to be replaced soon.  I'm now on my third plasma TV in 10 years but the Trinitron before it last 20 years. The first VCR I bought was made in Japan in 1984, cost near $400 and lasted 12 years. The first cell phone I bought was made in Finland 22 years ago and still works (but won't work outside North America and has to be supplemented.)  Since then I've gone through any number of cheap disposable  movie players, cell phones and iPhones made in China or southeast Asia.  CPI doesn't take into account the cumulative cost of junk.

Comment: Paul:  I was called when my Dad was in the hospital.  Flew down to California and went to the hospital.  Attendant took me to his room.. He had every conceiveable tube and electronic device in the room hooked up to him.  ..things didn't look good.

Doctor came in and I stepped out in the hall with him and asked him "what's the prognosis?"  He looked at me and said "Prognosis?"  I said "yeah, what's going on..."  He replied, "Your Dad is braindead."  I managed to contain myself and ask, "Then why do you have him hooked up to all that crap? What's the purpose?" (he had been being "maintained" for almost two days at this time).
He replied, "Well, there's really no purpose."  I said "then unplug all that "life-sustaining" stuff and let him pass away peacefully."  With my approval he did so.  

Between the insurance companies, the doctors and, let's not forget the attorneys, our health care system is, in my opinion, seriously FUBAR....call me if you don't know what FUBAR means
regards, Gary

Comment: The rest of the nation, outside of Vancouver and Toronto, is certainly not reasonably priced, let alone cheap.  It is only relative to those loony places that it appears so.  Prices are still way up almost everywhere, as measured by (1) Price to rental value {present value of rent}; (2) Price to historical price trend {regression or moving average}; or (3) Price to average family income.  If sellers hold on to units a little longer, they are hoping for one last bump before selling to fund their retirement.  When they DO finally sell, there will be a flood.  First boomers turn 71 this year, and they don't all have cushy DB pensions.  Read "When the Bubble Bursts" by Hilliard MacBeth.  
If you want to fix this idiocy, stop taxpayer-backed mortgage insurance, tax foreign buyers everywhere, quit selling citizenship, and scrap dual citizenship and ten year visas, etc.  Make the banks put money at risk when they lend! Comment: "...he was told to publicly revise some of [his] views...."

A person, such as Tony Flannery, thinks sincerely about important things and arrives at ideas, conclusions, and questions. Then a person in authority tells him to say publicly that those are not his thoughts. What exactly does the authority think is accomplished? That threatening someone until he mouths a lie is a moral act? That using threats and force to get such a statement is equivalent to the person changing his held, concluded ideas? That other people will be convinced by such a counterfeit, feigned makeover? The utter pettiness and triviality of the authority is what stands out here, the veniality and pompous arrogance, the valuing of surface over substance and depth. Do the authorities making this demand really imagine in this situation that anyone has been convinced by them? If they do, what shallow fools they are; if not, what malicious and torturing tyrants.

Comment: Waldman is right--and being politically very naive.  While Trump is truly an original in American politics (outside lunatic fringe candidates), this isn't the first time that the Republican party has nominated someone so odious that a significant part of the party's leadership defected to the Democrat candidate.

In 1884, the Republicans, against expectations, nominated James G. Blaine, senator from Maine.  Blaine, unlike Trump, had a long career in public service.  But his name had repeatedly been tainted with financial scandal.  Many party leaders ("Mugwumps)" refused to support Blaine on moral grounds.  The Democrats nominated the reformer Grover Cleveland.  The campaign was emotional and ugly on both sides.  Cleveland barely won the popular vote in New York state, and hence the presidency.  

Some high-ranking defectors aside, the Republicans will rally behind Trump because it's all they can do.  He is likely to lose, after which they will blame him, not themselves. So it goes.

Comment: Lots of fire dep'ts give away smoke detectors, e.g. Spokane, Mason County and even P.A. but they don't publicize it. If they go into a home on an aid call and note absence of a detector they'll offer it, or if someone comes to the hall and asks. I gave away detectors in Joyce until the commissioners officially reprimanded me for "an ethics violation ~ financial impropriety" because I'd offered them $500 to seed the program and they refused it, citing non-existent liability exposure. 
Their insurance agent denied there was any liability but the proud commish's said they knew better, so an ethics violation remains on my record at FPD4, even after these fools went to a state commissioners conference and were told there is NO liability for giving away detectors. Idiots. I quit Joyce FD long ago. Politics trumps fire prevention there. I suspect it's the same at other dept's where a little bit of power goes to peoples heads. They never recanted, apologized, or cleared my record, either.

There are many reasons to dislike the CAD.  Let us count the ways...
1.  The Canadian government is on a spending spree to stimulate domestic growth and will compete with private interests to borrow money, pressuring interest rates higher.
2.  Heavily indebted Canadians can't tolerate higher interest rates, so the Bank of Canada will try to sit on its hands or otherwise deal the housing bubble a lethal blow.
3.  The US is raising interest rates and cleaning up the Fed's balance sheet.  The Fed will sell bonds, pushing US interest rates higher, which is bearish for the CAD.
4.  The technical charts for the CAD are bearish.  The break below 80 cents US in 2015 implies a downside target of 55 cents.
5.  Oil will trade between $34 and $55 for years.  We are at the high end of the range and struggling to stay there.
I share neither Mr. Rosenberg's optimism nor his agenda.

Comment: Dave, to call the OIA selfish, petty and spiteful is way out of line.  Here is what needs to be said about OIA versus ILH competition: IT'S NOT A LEVEL PLAYING FIELD.  The big ILH programs can cherry-pick talent from across the state with no restrictions and can afford better facilities, better equipment, and more and better coaches.  The OIA's sole advantage is that it has far more teams, which increases the probability that in any given year it can field one or two teams capable of competing head-to-head with the ILH's elite.  Under those circumstances it should be no surprise at all that the OIA is opposed to any playoff format that could force its champion to beat two top ILH teams to win a state title.  Knocking off the ILH's best is already asking a lot given the ILH's intrinsic advantages.

I agree with you that it's unfortunate that the end result has been to decrease the overall size of the playoffs and a better compromise is needed.  But don't trash the OIA as the culprit.

Comment: A rather delayed response. Imagine that a retailer sells chicken for R 30/kg. The retailer has an invoice price for that chicken of R 25/kg meaning a R 5 GP. Written into the supply agreement is that the chicken supplier will pay for various marketing expenses via rebates, shelf fees etc. which costs the supplier R 5/kg.  The chicken supplier nets R 20/kg. If the retailer paid for all the marketing costs themselves the chicken supplier still gets R 20/kg, the retailer still sells the chicken for R 30/kg but the retailer GP is now R 10/kg. This changes the way the retailers books are presented.

Comment: Don't touch the PFD.

Do cut more.

Kill the tax credits.

Implement a flat ~10% income tax.

Implement a stiff seasonal sales tax.  Exclude necessities that residents rely on such as unprepared food, medicine, utilities, etc.  Tourists would finally pay their share.

While the flat income tax is more regressive than a graduated tax, it also would be more politically acceptable.  Everyone would pay the same percentage.  Everyone would pay something (the PFD check would be taxable income).  The rich would pay more.  It's relatively simple and straight-forward to implement.  Out of state workers would finally pay their share.

Imposing taxes would wake up voters.  As long as free money magically appears and pays for all of our government services, it's easy to just go fishing and trust someone else to run things. That's how we end up with Taj Mahawkers.  Our legislators feel no accountability to us.  Once government funding comes out of our wallets, we pay attention.  And vote.

Comment: dem·a·gogue ˈdeməˌɡäɡ/ noun
a political leader who seeks support by appealing to popular desires and prejudices rather than by using rational argument.

Demagoguery is an appeal to people that plays on their emotions and prejudices rather than on their rational side. Demagoguery is a manipulative approach — often associated with dictators and sleazy politicians — that appeals to the worst nature of people.

Comment: This pairing of "crackpot" and "theories" shows a profound ignorance of what a scientific theory is.  Quoting Wikipedia:
"A scientific theory is an explanation of some aspect of the natural world that can be repeatedly tested, in accordance with the scientific method, by using a predefined protocol of observations and experiments. Established scientific theories have withstood rigorous scrutiny and are a comprehensive form of scientific knowledge...
In everyday non-scientific speech, 'theory' can imply that something is an unsubstantiated and speculative guess, conjecture, idea, or, hypothesis; such a usage is the opposite of the word 'theory' in science.... The strength of a scientific theory is related to the diversity of phenomena it can explain. As additional scientific evidence is gathered, a scientific theory may be rejected or modified if it does not fit the new findings; in such circumstances, a more accurate theory is then desired."

Comment: "The rest of the world is struggling to find balanced ways to reduce carbon emissions"?  Rubbish!  

China's commitment so far is to continue to increase it's carbon output till 2033, when it will begin to consider otherwise.

The Indian government says it will reduce carbon emissions 33 to 35% by 2030.  Sounds great eh?  Until you read the fine print . . . lower the rate relative to its GDP.  India's GHG emissions are soaring and will continue to do so.  

Now with the USA out of the game, Trudeau doubles down on his pledge to euthanise the Canadian economy with a carbon tax, even though Canada produces only 1.8% of global GHG's.  And Canada's vast boreal forests absorb more CO2 than Canada emits!  All this for mere symbolism. 

Trudeau is going to drive Canada's economy into the dumpster for a plan that, even if it succeeds, will do nothing to alter the rate or direction of climate change.

Comment: Yes it's true. The first time I used Amazon was last fall and I found the whole procedure astonishing; they made it practically idiot - proof.

I designated my local postal outlet as the preferred mailing address. The product was valued at $39 and shipping was free from Mississauga, promised within 5 business days to White Rock BC. It arrived in 2 ... now try going to the post office and sending the same parcel from Ontario to BC - the cost alone! Here is the most startling feature - an email was sent from Amazon to me which stated that the "shipment has arrived and will be returned within 14 days if not picked up and YOU WILL RECEIVE A FULL REFUND" 

Wow! Beat that Walmart.

In addition I visited my computer savvy friend in Seattle during April and before he took me on a tour of the Amazon warehouse area, which is beyond huge, he pointed to the neighbors across the street and said that they never visit a mall or store since they do all their shopping online, including groceries.

Comment: There are many examples of technological disruptors who succeeded to push "old-line" incumbents out far faster than investors anticipated or the incumbents could adapt. Here are a few...
- In 2008, Blockbuster CEO Jim Keyes told the Motley Fool that Netflix "isn't even on the radar screen in terms of competition". Just 2 years later, Blockbuster filed for bankruptcy.
- In 2006, Palm CEO Ed Colligan said of the newly announce iPhone "They’re not going to just walk in." Just 2 years later, Palm stopped making PDAs.
- In 2011, Nintendo president Reggie Fils-Aime dismissed mobile games. Just 4 years later, mobile game revenue overtook console game revenue.
- In 1977, DEC founder Ken Olsen said "There is no reason anyone would want a computer in their home,". Just 4 years later, IBM introduced the PC. Once the 2nd largest computer company in the world, DEC is now a footnote.

Comment: 1-Lumping all Native corporations together , while common, is useless. There are the for- profit Regionals, there are  non-profit and for-profit village corporations, etc. Some of the corporations are charged with governmental responsibilities , many not. 
The Regs, the big ones,  must be run as for-profit corporations with duties to shareholders for dividends. They can fund some non-profit activities, mine does, but their primary function is to make money for enrolled shareholders. It is estimated that about 50% of afterborns statewide have no shares and thus are not eligible for dividends from a Reg. 
2- Celia is sort of correct about the Federal government having a responsibility for healthcare  for Alaska Natives. The federal  law changed in relatively recent years for Native peoples to administer , under supervised contracts, their own health care- hence outfits like YKHC. Between underfunding and challenges like staffing things get tough- like this article points out.
